												Russian Car Driver is a shovelware game that's not even a GOOD shovelware game. Taking heavily after "skill-based" driving games such as Driver and Gran Turismo, the game puts you in control of a boxy Russian sedan I call the Vladmobile.The Vladmobile is not governed by any of the laws of physics or common sense, something you'll figure out in the game's required first mode: Parking. Parking mode consists of navigating the Vladmobile through a path made out of traffic cones and stopping it in a glowing "park zone" within a time limit. What you'll soon figure out are two things:First, parking mode is really glitchy and a lot of the time it's easy to slip out of bounds between the cones (touching a cone automatically fails you) and slip back in at the park zone.Second, the Vladmobile does not accelerate or brake in a consistent manner. I spent probably ten minutes of the hour I played this game before refunding it figuring out exactly how the physics work. The answer is that they don't. The Vladmobile will not stop simply because you stopped pressing the accelerator or the reverse - you have to figure out that spacebar is the "handbrake" button, which causes the car to come to an absolute dead stop the second you use it. While the handbrake does make parking mode a lot easier, it's not something that comes naturally or is easy to figure out, especially if you're used to driving in games like Grand Theft Auto V that use realistic driving physics.Once you get past parking mode, you get to the game's second unlockable mode: drifting. Drifting mode is actually impossible with the default settings - you can't drift properly with the "Anti-Lock Brakes" and "ESP Brakes" settings on. With them off, the car goes from controlling like a 18th-century pirate ship to controlling like a stick of butter covered in bacon grease. Drifting mode is extremely easy to clear, since it uses the same course layout for all of the "trials" and the only differences are the time limit and the score you're expected to get. With all of the brake settings off, I was able to do this pretty much effortlessly by building up speed and then hitting left and right alternating until the game broke and gave me thousands of points.Oh, one thing I should mention about drifting mode: by default, the Vladmobile will not go over 60 miles per hour. To get it to go faster, you have to change the game to manual transmission - which uses controls not listed anywhere in the game itself (A upshifts gears by default, Z downshifts). However, manual transmission is a nightmare because being in the wrong gear for any period of time will cause your engine to explode, automatically failing whatever challenge you're on. Assuming you figure out parking and drifting mode, you then get to move on to the game's final mode, Drag Racing. Unlike Parking or Drifting, Drag Racing forces you to use manual transmission without any warning whatsoever, so if you have no experience with it you'll be wondering why your engine keeps exploding the second you touch the accelerator. I was completely and utterly unable to finish even the first stage of Drag Racing mode, mostly because of the terrible handling on the Vladmobile and the constant siege of oncoming traffic. The game is not good for speedrunning, it's not good for streaming, and it's certainly not fun. Don't think that because it cost you $0.69 that it's worth it - even paying that little promotes shovelware on Steam.

												The idea of this game is not necessarily like the title. Yes, the VAZ 2108 'Vladmobile' is Russian, but that's the only car included. It means what it says "Russain Car Driver", that's it - you drive A Russian car. The game howerver, is centered around the 2108. There are little icons placed all around with some short facts or history about it and an accompanying picture. I think the free roam mode was my favorite if I had to have one. The translations could use some work in the story mode, so could the auto transmission in general. For some odd reason, it shifts into neural every time it tries to upshift. It even has this problem in manual mode, which is really weird considering the in-game trans relies on user input. I can only assume that it's because of the clutch. The cars don't deform much graphically, but it is funny to drive around with the front wheels literally in the front. I like that some objects around the world are movable, and there's a way from one map to another. The textures aren't the greatest, but what can you expect from a .99 game? They remind me of gmod in a way, so it doesn't bother me that much. I enjoy the radio, I don't usually listen to Russian rap/hip-hop. It really improves the Russianness of this game. I have yet to unlock the custom paints, but it's nice to be able to change the default collor of the car. As Timrod put it, Originally posted by Timrod: Drifting mode is actually impossible with the default settings - you can't drift properly with the "Anti-Lock Brakes" and "ESP Brakes" settings on. With them off, the car goes from controlling like a 18th-century pirate ship to controlling like a stick of butter covered in bacon grease.  I recommend you turn all the car's aids off, and use man mode for ultimate usability. Try to shift around 2-3 on the revs, anything over will stop it. As others have noted, the police will not chase you for more than a few seconds. I'm really disappointed by this, another broken mechanic. It might be fixable through the game's files, but I don't care enough to look into it. As far as I'm concerned, I paid for the music I guess, and bits of history I could have found with Google if I was really that adamant to learn about it. This game still needs work, but it could turn into something interesting. Include more VAZ cars, their history, fix the transmission, and police chases. Then this would be acceptable to release.

												First and foremost - this game can be found for free online and played in your browser.  Russian Car Driver is a very clunky game that's hard to recommend.  If you're looking for something to roam the Russian countryside in and run over bears or deer then it might be up your alley.  But if you're looking for any sort of legitimate, fun racing experience then this isn't the game for you.  Your car controls more akin to a tank than a car.  The graphics are more reminiscent of the early 2000's/late 90's.  If you play in English then expect a lot of broken English that makes some wording a bit weird.  The game does have some okay music, though.  And I guess you learn a fair amount about the history of the Russian automobile industry.  This game could be worse - but it can also be a lot, lot better.  Even with some polishing it could potentially turn out at least okay - there are definitely some features in there that could work.  But right now I can't recommend people dropping their money on it.  If you're interested in seeing how it actually plays (with some horrible commentary):

I'd like to propose that this game is truly great because of the important questions it raises.. it really tests your mind and your capacity to ponder complex concepts: "How am I still driving if my front wheels are clipping into my car's bonnet?", "Why did that fence I just drove into send me 100ft into the air?", "I wonder how fast I can go if every time I level up I upgrade max speed and engine power?".These are just a few examples of some of the ways this game will test you, not your driving skills, but your mind...

Russian Car Driver Review Russian Car Driver is one of the best driving games to be released this year. The graphics and mechanics of the game far surpass the new Forza, The Crew, Burnout and Need for Speed. The game has an emphasis on challege and will really test you to ensure you are playing to your full potential. There are several game modes to Russian Car Driver each of which have three difficulty being beginner, middle and professional. There seems to be tweleve levels in each difficulty and each level has a ranking system of either "1 place, 2 place, or 3 place" with 1 place being the best. These are awared either on time or points and failing to meet the conditions causes you to fail the mission.Freeride Mode Freeride mode is the where you can follow along with the games story, contacting NPC's with your phone and performing missions for them. The missions you do in Freeride Mode are the same as the missions on the main menu but come about at random times when the NPC's contact you through your phone. There are two story areas for Freeride Mode, Countryside and Offroad and as well as selecting the area, you can select the weather or if you just want to drive without the story.Missions There are various types of missions in Russian Car Driver, these missions being Drag Racing, Drifting, Parking, Rally and Racing. Each mission playing as expected, you drift for points in the drifting mission, you perform a series of parking challenges in Parking, etc. Drifting has a Free Driftmode where you can practive drifting if needed.Car CustomisationWhile the customisation is limited, it is still a lovely feature for the game, allowing the players to choose various colours for their car body and rims to personalise their experience. There are also Exclusive Styles which are acquired by completing the various challenges in the game.OptionsThere is a plethora of graphical options for this game, and it even comes with its own graphical filters to make the game look even better, but at a cost of framerate, meaning if you want to run this game at the highest setting you may need to splash out on a decent graphics card.The audio options are however lacking, as I can only tune the Master, Radio and Engine volume. The game would benefit from adding volumes sliders for other options, such as cows, birdsong and flowing rivers. It would also benefit from adding various sounds such as city chatter and maybe wolves howling.Like the audio options, the controls are lacking seeing as you can not rebind the keys at all. The cameral controls for the game are difficult as there is no way to use the y-axis in the game to look up and down, only left and right. This can cause some confusion as there is no way of knowing what is infront of you. They have added a bonnet and interior camera to help with this, but I would prefer if they had 360 degrees camera control.Pros and ConsHere I will list a few Pros and Cons of Russian Car Driver:ProsNice music I guessThere are animalsConsThe car controls like a hot wheels car three loose wheels and one missing wheelThe car likes to randomly stall for no reasonThe car speeds up and slows down randomlyThe car's 0-60mph takes about an hourThe mud in the rally race (which you have to go through) does not slow down the car, it stalls itThe car likes to stall when changing gearSome of the car skins don't even have texturesDrifting just means driving round in a circle to gain points, the checkpoints are pointlessOverallOverall I would highly recommend Russian Car Driver for its new and inovative gameplay and at the current price it would be stupid not to pick it up.

												Russian Car Driver is a fun car driving game.For what it is, a cheap game being sold for 99 cents on Steam, it's great (although, I must admit, I bought it on sale for 69c).If you want to buy a game as good as Grand Theft Auto, then you've come to the wrong place - this is just a cheap game that provides some light entertainment.Don't take this game too seriously, just have some fun with it.I read a few of the reviews about the game before I bought it; and, although some people hated it, others gave it a thumbs up.So I thought that there must be some good in it - why not give it a go?The graphics are 1990's style, so there is nothing special there.And the car mechanics are just ok.However, nonetheless, I actually really enjoyed playing Russian Car Driver.I had fun driving around the Russian countryside in my indestructible little car.The occasional bear on the road adds to the Russian ambience of the game.I've smashed through piles of logs, gone flying through the air (due to deliberately bad driving), and have done lots of cross-country travelling.Great stuff!Some reviewers mentioned that the steering wasn't too responsive, so the first thing I did before playing was to maximise the steering ability in the options - so that might have helped give me a positive experience with the game.You can bash into anything with your car, and it just keeps on going.After I went through a massive mud puddle, I thought I would try driving into into a river to wash the mud off - but, doh, it turns out that doing so was a bridge too far, and the car had to be rescued (whilst you can't drive for too long in water, I have managed to quickly drive across a river and survive).Naturally, if you bash into solid objects (such as trees or houses) you will come to a complete stop (but your car can just drive off again).If you are going fast enough, you can pretty much smash through anything else (e.g. fences, piles of logs, animals).If you speed past a cop car, they will give chase; but you can pretty much always get away from them really easily (I got caught only once, when I made a mistake and crashed directly into a police vehicle).You can speed across country. I haven't noticed any difference in the speed you can attain on the roads or in the fields - which, obviously, is unrealistic, but it all adds to the fun of the game.I've even driven up to the top of the hills/mountains which are the barriers for the edge of the map, just for a bit of amusement.However, be careful of the big slabs of rock which appear in fields, as I got myself stuck on rock formations twice in the game, so I am assuming it can happen to other players too.There are missions to be done.When you complete a mission, you can upgrade aspects of your car, such as speed and steering.There is also a radio that you can play whilst driving around, although the music is a bit blah - but it does have half a dozen radio stations to choose from.You need to turn down the other in-game sounds to be able to hear the radio better.It would be great if you could import your own music into the radio (although you could just play your own music on another programme whilst the game is running, I suppose).The radio list includes a Russian station, so there's another addition to the Russian ambience.I had a lot of fun with this - loved it!There is definitely more than 99 cents worth of fun in this game.Russian Car Driver is not meant to be on par with the top-grade racing or car driving games on the market, so just enjoy it for what it is - a good bit of fun.
